ratings.comment: Professor Shi cares about his student. he gives careful review of the material and is willing to repeat the part that I got confused on. Very reachable during office hour, recommend to take his class.

The grading cutoff for this course is so high unlike other undergrad courses. Lectures are dull, proofs are exactly the same as it is in the textbooks. You don't need to go to class, just read the book. Lots of homework and exam-heavy. Kind of stingy with extra points. His finals are usually extremely hard. Avoid him and take someone else.

Number theory is a tough course, so one assumes to have good background in abstract algebra. I think the department should also add Math 542 as its prerequisite since there is much more knowledge to be assumed before taking this course. Though I was not a big fan of the textbook selection since it contains no useful examples except Sage.

He assigns lots of homework every week and he's very stingy about giving extra points. He is in favor of in-class exams; 2 midterms and 1 final. iI is a GPA killer since he seems to have no clear criteria about grading. The lectures are quite hard to follow as he skips so many steps. The exams are very hard; you need 90% to get an A.

He comes down with arrogance when asked a question in class for some reason. The tests are unreasonably hard as he boasts about making the exams intentionally harder in class. The lectures are boring, and the proofs are sloppy but he expects you to do perfectly on the exam ... did not learn anything from his lectures. Waste of money

Yousheng is a great guy and very approachable during office hours. He cares about the students doing well in class. The final exam was quite difficult but his grading is quite generous. He is very easy going and down to earth unlike many other professors at the math department, quite snobby and arrogant. Take him and avoid Laurentiu Maxim.

Lectures are a dry, worse version of the textbook, which is bad news because the textbook he picked is no good. Handwriting is unreadable both in the answer keys and on the blackboard. If you ask him a hard question he skips everything. If you ask him an easy question he crawls through it. Grading/exams was really generous tho.

Yousheng cares about his students and their success in the course. Math 542 is a tough and difficult course. However, his lectures are very clear to follow. The office hours are very useful and he does a good job on explaining how to think. His grading criteria is different but he is a good instructor for advanced math courses. Highly recommended.

My biggest problem is that it seems like he is teaching grad students. I have seen practice exams from other professors and heard about the class from others, and the class seems much easier. There were so many theoretical applications and proofs that sometimes it felt more like an English class. I guess I have a deeper understanding though.

I don't really understand why there are so many negative comment on prof. Shi. As a Chinese newly trasferred student, I think he has made things pretty clear(if you find it harder and harder to understand his lectures, I think the only reason is you even didn't try to understand the last lecture by reviewing)

This is easily the worst class I have taken. This course made me hate math. I went to lectures and took notes on all lecture material, but I learned little from Professor Shi. Most of my learning came from reading the textbook. Going to lectures was a waste of time. Even discussions were useless as the TA often explained concepts wrong.

His lectures are awful and he provides no feedback or resources. He over explains the really easy stuff and then gives no explanation on very difficult topics. He is unclear about his grading policies and doesnt care about his students at all. One of the worse classes I have ever taken. Avoid him at all cost

Unless you already know the material and are taking the class for kicks, the only way to pass is to teach yourself from the textbook. Complete waste of tuition money to take his section. By the second exam, the majority of the class stopped going to his lectures and probably got better grades because of it.
Shouldn't be teaching students, he doesn't care about teaching at all.
He's a terrible lecturer and writes very small on the board. Also not good at explaining concepts.

While every other professors in the university are trying to help students navigate through the challenge caused by the outbreak, this professor is giving ZERO resource to the students and he is even restricting his already non-existing resource as he assumes some student are cheating in class. Honestly, the worst teacher I've had in my life.

The textbook explains better than he does. He is also paranoid about cheating-direct quote from an email regarding final exam, "So in order to prevent cheating, I will not provide a practice exam". Ok, the content isnt hard, but I see him not showing ANY respect to students by not preparing for lectures and offering students proper resources.

Like others have said, his lectures are extremely confusing, and we sometimes think he doesn't know what he is talking about. I am so regretful that I took his class, waste of money and didn't learn anything. Not only he is pretty bad at teaching, but also his grading policy is also harsh. I wish I saw all these reviews before took his class. :(

His lecture is to be honest confusing. He did not really make it clear to students I even doubt the he figured it out himself. Though he is honest and respected, his teaching part still need a lot improve.

Like many others have said, his lectures are almost entirely him just reading from the textbook. If he's your only option don't be too worried. A lot of his lectures are definitely confusing, but it could be worse. Fortunately, none of the homework was graded and quizzes were only every other week.

class is not well taught i don't think its fair to assume students can self-teach and intuitively understand these concepts with such little help i cant even say he's my professor if sal khan taught me more 340 than he did

Don't take this class unless you want to sit in lectures completely and utterly confused learning stuff you don't even need to know and completely learning everything yourself from the textbook. I would NOT recommend this class, choose another one or a different professor if you can.
Zero learning in the lecture room (textbook is better than the prof). All of the learning came from the discussion (I had a good TA) and youtube.

This is a math class, but I need to read more than humanity or literature classes because it is hard to learn from him. His blackboard note is whatever in the textbook. He doesn't have interactions during lectures or explain any concepts. I feel like I wasted thousands of dollars taking his class because I need to always learn again from youtube.
If you enjoy self-studying for an advanced math class, he is definitely the professor you are looking for. He doesn't seem to care about his lectures.

It's true that he writes things from the textbook to blackboard, but I think students always need to self learning something in college. His handwriting is clear and gives clear homework instructions. And he just graduated from the grad school, so I think he did pretty well as a new prof. Needs time to improve tho

This professor simply doesn't teach well. He is very fast (too fast) and expects students to catch up to his PhD pace. He just writes whatever is already written in the textbook and doesn't bother explaining the concept with the level that students can understand.
He cannot express his point clearly.
